qas.question: What provides a solution to a list of integers provided as input that ned to be sorted?
When extensive time is required to sort integers, this represents what case complexity?
What is the expression used to denote a worst case complexity as expressed by time taken?
What does not solve the problem of sorting a list of integers that is given as the input?

plausible_answers.text: solves the problem of sorting a list of integers that is given as the input.

qas.question: What does the deterministic parting algorithm quicksort do?
What case complexity is represented when limited time is required to sort integers?
What is the expression not used to denote worst case complexity as expressed by time taken?
What case complexity is represented when each pivoting divides the list in thirds, also needing O(n log n) time?

context: For example, consider <a0_2>the <a0_0><b3_0>deterministic sorting algorithm <a0_1>quicksort<b3_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. This <b4_0>solves the problem of sorting a list of integers that is given as the input.<b4_0/> The <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b5_0>worst<a1_1/>-case<b5_0/><a1_2/><a1_0/> is when the input is sorted or sorted in reverse order, and the algorithm takes time <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>O(n2)<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> for this case. If we assume that all possible permutations of the input list are equally likely, the average time taken for sorting is <b6_0>O(n log n)<b6_0/>. The <b7_0>best case<b7_0/> occurs when each pivoting divides the list in half, also needing O(n log n) time.
